info.title: Agenteux.ai REST APIs
info.description:
# Agenteux.ai: The AgentOps Platform for AI Agent Ecosystems

Agenteux.ai offers a full suite of APIs to treat AI agents as first-class citizens in your technology stack.
Its suite of modular services delivers developer tools to improve development productivity, agent reliability and predictability, limit runaway LLM costs and agent abuse, and improve end-to-end visibility across the AI agent development lifecycle.

### Core Components

| Service | Purpose |
| :-- | :-- |
| **Agenteux: Schema** | Centralized schema management for `Structured Output Parsing`, data transformation, and inter-agent contracts. Create, version, validate, and publish reusable schemas to standardize communication between agents, APIs, and tools. |
| **Agenteux: Prompt** | Complete prompt management system. Create, test, and version LLM prompt templates with substitutable variables, A/B testing, analytics, and rollback capabilities. |
| **Agenteux: Security** | Purpose-built API security and control. Enable authentication, rate limiting, usage-based billing, and compliance for agent-driven traffic. |
| **Agenteux: Toggle** | Dynamic runtime control. Manage feature flags, rollouts, experiments, and kill switches for agents without redeployment. |
| **Agenteux: Domain** | Full white-label and custom domain management for branded agent experiences. Support for SSL, DNS, and multi-tenant branding. |
| **Agenteux: Link** | Smart link management for agent communications. Generate branded, trackable, and workflow-aware URLs with analytics and automation. |

---

## üß© Unified AgentOps Experience

All Agenteux services are fully **API-first** and designed for interoperability:

- Centralized dashboard for cross-service visibility  
- Unified team management and access control  
- Consistent JSON-based policy model across components  
- Real-time monitoring and analytics  
- SDKs for Python, JavaScript, Java, and Go  

The platform seamlessly integrates into modern AI architectures, whether you‚Äôre building autonomous agents, LLM-based assistants, or complex multi-agent workflows.

---

## üè¢ Built for Enterprise Scale

Agenteux.ai delivers production-grade features out of the box:

- **Security & Compliance:** Multi-tenant access controls, audit logging, and data residency options  
- **Reliability:** 99.99% uptime SLA and global availability zones  
- **Private Cloud:** Deploy on-premises or in dedicated environments  
- **Integration:** Native support for OAuth, SSO, and CI/CD pipelines  
- **Observability:** Comprehensive telemetry and event streaming  

---

## üöÄ Why Agenteux.ai

- **Accelerate Deployment:** Move from prototype to production much faster, treating prompts, schemas, security as code
- **Reduce Complexity:** Replace ad-hoc tooling with a unified stack with simpler workflows
- **Control Costs:** Enforce rate limits, track usage, and optimize API and LLM spend
- **Increase Reliability:** Ensure consistent agent behavior and schema compatibility
- **Enable Innovation:** Focus on agent design instead of infrastructure management

---

## üîó Learn More

- **Website:** [https://www.agenteux.ai](https://www.agenteux.ai)  
- **Docs:** [https://docs.agenteux.ai](https://docs.agenteux.ai)  
- **Demo:** [https://www.agenteux.ai/demo](https://www.agenteux.ai/demo)  
- **Support:** [support@agenteux.ai](mailto:support@agenteux.ai)

---

*Agenteux.ai ‚Äî Where AI Agents Meet Enterprise Infrastructure.*

tags.name: Accounts
tags.description: Multi-tenancy Management API: Management of customer accounts. Accounts may be hierarchical.

tags.name: Client Applications
tags.description: Management of OIDC/OAuth2 client applications and their access credentials.

tags.name: API Keys
tags.description:
Management of Static API Keys.

A Static API Key is:
  - A pre-defined API key that is associated (statically) with a Rate Plan.
  - An example is Tenant ID associated to a tenant SLA-related Rate Plan.
  - Static API keys can also be utilized as authorization tokens for your API consumers.

A Dynamic API Key is:
  - An API key that is assigned a Rate Plan at runtime (instead of statically pre-associated).
  - Use these when there are a large quantity or they cannot be know beforehand.
  - Some examples are IP address, user ID, device ID.
  - Dynamic values can be pulled from the request context via scripting and used for Dynamic API keys.

tags.name: JWT Verifiers
tags.description: Management of OAuth2 and/or OIDC token verifiers.

tags.name: Policies
tags.description:
Management of Rate-Limting Policies.

A Policy stitches API keys, rate plans and JWT verifiers together into an enforcable set of rules. It is used at run-time to enforce rate-limits and, optionally, authorization.

Each category of API call in your system will have different Policies to enforce SLAs.

A Policy is made up of the following rules or statements:
  * Authorization Statement (see below)
    - Only included if authorization enforcement at the edge is desired.
    - An Authorization Statement can enforce Static API Key or OAuth2 or OpenID Connect (OIDC) JWT verification authorization.
  * API Key Statements
    - An array of Static and/or Dynamic API Keys on which to enforce rate-limiting (via Rate Plans).
    - Dynamic API Keys are associated to a Rate Plan in the API Key Statement.
    - Static API Keys do not include a Rate Plan in the statment.
    - API Key values can be extracted from the incoming request context using script snippets.
    - One or more API Key Statements must be present in the Policy.
  * Error Handling Statement
# Authorization Statements
  - By including an Authorization Statement in a rate-limiting Policy, the Policy can perform request authorization by validating an API Key or a Java Web Token (JWT).
  * API Key Authorization
      - Static API Keys can be validated in requests to authorize API consumers by using scripting in the Policy to extract the API key from the request.
      - If the Static API Key exists, the consumer is assumed to be authorized.
      - Not as secure as using JWT authorization (below).
  * Java Web Token Authorization
      - Configuring a JWT Verifier and including it in a rate-limiting Policy enables issuer, audience, expiration and signature validation for incoming requests.
      - Validates tokens at the edge so invalid tokens don't load up back-end services.
      - Script snippets can be included in issuer and audience configuration to enable dynamic validation with values substituted from the incoming request context
      (e.g. a multi-tenant authorization server).

tags.name: Prompts
tags.description: Prompt management operations.

tags.name: Prompt Versions
tags.description: Prompt versioning operations.

tags.name: Rate Limiting
tags.description:
Rate-limiting oriented requests.

An API gateway or other application calls the `/limits` endpoint to see if the request is allowed or denied.
- The response returns a 'decision' property containing `ALLOW` or `DENY` that the application or API gateway uses to enforce the decision.
- A rate-limiting request includes data from the original request such as headers and other parameters (maybe even from the body). This
becomes the request context from which Policy script snippets can extract values.
- It also includes the Policy (either the `slug` or `ID`) that should be applied to the request. __NOTE:__ Using the `ID` is more performant than using the `slug`.
- The execution of the Policy causes counters to be maintained in the system tracking API Key counters against their associated Rate Plans.

tags.name: Rate-Limiting Metrics
tags.description:
Rate-limiting metrics/analytics endpoints.

Rate-limiting Policy execution maintains stateful counters for each API Key that is active (has been used recently). These can be inspected at any time via an API call.

tags.name: Rate Plans
tags.description:
Management of individual rate plans.

A RatePlan defines quota and/or throttling (aka spike arrest) configuration that can be applied to both static or dynamic API keys during a rate-limiting decision request.

For example, there may be rate plans for tenants, applications, devices, all with different quota and throttling characteristics.

Each Rate Plan can have either or both of 'quota' and 'throttle':
- Quota is a fixed-time window rate-limit over an hour, day, week or month. Quota applies SLAs or license limits to API consumers.
- Throttle is a rolling window of budgeted usage for traffic-shaping over a shorter time period of hours, minutes, or seconds.

organizationId.description: Your organization id or organization name. Note that it is more efficient to use the organization ID assigned to you rather than the organization name as the latter causes an extra lookup to find the ID and also has the potential to break if the organization name is changed.

get.summary: List all the accounts associated with the organization (paginated)

200.description: An array of accounts in this organization.

post.summary: Create a new account within this organization.

201.description: Successful account creation. Returns the newly-created account metadata.

get.summary: Read an account configuration (by ID or slug)

200.description: Account configuration details.

put.summary: Update an account configuration (by ID or slug)

delete.summary: Remove an entire account (by ID or slug)

patch.summary: Perform a partial update of an account (by ID or slug).
patch.description: This method observes JSON patch semantics. Any properties that are explicity set (e.g. to empty) will update the Account. Properties not included in the body will not effect the Account configuration.

200.description: The entire newly-updated account.

get.summary: List all the client applications (paginated)

200.description: An array of client applications and associated configuration metadata

post.summary: Create a new OAuth2/OIDC client application.

201.description: Successful client application creation. Returns the newly-created client configuration metadata

get.summary: Read a client application configuration (by ID or name)

200.description: Client application configuration metadata

put.summary: Update a client application configuration (by ID or name)

delete.summary: Remove a client application (by ID or name)

patch.summary: Perform a partial update of a client application configuration (by ID or name).
patch.description: This method observes JSON patch semantics. Any properties that are explicity set (e.g. to empty) will update the Client. Properties not included in the body will not effect the Client configuration.

200.description: The entire newly-updated Client application.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description:
The filter crieteria to apply to the prompts list.

Allowed filter properties are `id` and `slug`.  For example, `filter="slug eq my-prompt"` to filter by slug.

See [Filtering](https://docs.example.com/api/filtering) for more details.

get.summary: List all the Prompts (paginated)

200.description: An array of prompts and their details.

post.summary: Create a new prompt

201.description: Successful prompt creation. Returns the newly-created prompt details including the initial version and description of any variables.

get.summary: Retrieve a prompt

200.description: Prompt details including the latest prompt text and version.

requestBody.description: All the desired prompt details. Only name, slug, and description can be updated.

200.description: Prompt details including the latest prompt text and version.

delete.summary: Remove a prompt (and all its versions)

patch.summary: Perform a partial update of a prompt
patch.description:
This method observes [JSON patch](https://jsonpatch.com/) semantics. Any properties that are explicity set
(e.g. to empty) will update the prompt configuration. Properties not included in
the body will not effect the prompt configuration.

requestBody.description: Prompt details to be updated. Only the fields provided will be updated. Only name, slug, and description can be updated with PATCH.

200.description: The entire newly-updated prompt

post.summary: Perform variable substitution on a prompt (using the latest version)

requestBody.description: Submit the variables as name/value pairs to be substituted into the prompt.

200.description: The entire prompt metadata including the prompt text with variables substituted.

get.summary: List all the versions for a prompt (paginated)

200.description: An array of prompt versions and their details.

post.summary: Create a new prompt version

201.description: Successful prompt creation. Returns the newly-created prompt details including the initial version and description of any variables.

get.summary: Retrieve a specific prompt version

200.description: Prompt details for the specific version.

patch.summary: Perform a partial update of a prompt

requestBody.description: Prompt details to be updated. Only the fields provided will be updated. Only name, slug, and description can be updated with PATCH.

200.description: The entire newly-updated prompt

post.summary: Perform variable substitution on a prompt version

requestBody.description: Submit the variables as name/value pairs to be substituted into the prompt version.

200.description: The entire prompt metadata including the substituted prompt text.

get.summary: Retrieve the prompt template for a specific prompt version
get.description: Retrieve the prompt template for the specified prompt version. Variables in the template will be in the form `{{variable-name}}`.

200.description: The prompt template for the specific version.

parameters.name: redirect
parameters.description:
If set, after performing the substitution, the response will be a 302 redirect to the URL specified by this parameter, with the substituted prompt appended to the end of the url. Thus, the query parameter must be in the string (e.g., named "q"). This is useful for integrating with ChatGPT-like services that accept prompt input via a URL query parameter.
Short-hand values are also supported for common services:
  - "chatgpt": redirects to `https://chatgpt.com/?q=`
  - "claude": redirects to `https://claude.ai/new/?q=`
  - "perplexity": redirects to `https://perplexity.com/?q=`
  - "google_search": redirects to `https://www.google.com/search?q=`

post.summary: Perform variable substitution on a prompt template
post.description:
Perform variable substitution on the prompt template for the specified prompt version. Submit the variables as name/value pairs in the request body, and the response will be the prompt template with the variables substituted.
If the `redirect` query-string parameter is set, after performing the substitution, the response will be a 302 redirect to the URL specified by this parameter, with the substituted prompt appended to the end of the url. This is useful for integrating with ChatGPT-like services that accept prompt input via a URL query parameter.

requestBody.description: Submit the variables as name/value pairs to be substituted into the prompt template.

200.description: The prompt template with the variables substituted.

302.description: If the 'redirect' query-string parameter is set, redirect to the specified URL (or shorh-hand URL) with the substituted prompt.

get.summary: Retrieve the prompt variables for a specific prompt version

200.description: Prompt variables for the specific version.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description:
The filter crieteria to apply to the schema list.

Allowed filter properties are `id` and `slug`.  For example, `filter="slug eq my-schema"` to filter by slug.

See [Filtering](https://docs.example.com/api/filtering) for more details.

200.description: An array of schemas and their details.

post.summary: Create a new schema

201.description: Successful schema creation. Returns the newly-created schema details including the initial version.

get.summary: Retrieve a schema

200.description: Schema details including the latest schema text and version.

requestBody.description: All the desired schema details. Only name, slug, and description can be updated.

200.description: Schema details including the latest schema text and version.

delete.summary: Remove a schema (and all its versions)

patch.summary: Perform a partial update of a schema
patch.description:
This method observes [JSON patch](https://jsonpatch.com/) semantics. Any properties that are explicity set
(e.g. to empty) will update the schema configuration. Properties not included in
the body will not effect the schema configuration.

requestBody.description: Schema details to be updated. Only the fields provided will be updated. Only name, slug, and description can be updated with PATCH.

200.description: The entire newly-updated schema details including the latest schema text and version.

post.summary: Perform data verification against a schema

requestBody.description: The data to be verified against the schema.

200.description: The result of the data verification.

get.summary: List all the versions for a schema (paginated)

200.description: An array of schema versions and their details.

post.summary: Create a new schema version

201.description: Successful schema creation. Returns the newly-created schema details including the initial version.

get.summary: Retrieve a specific schema version

200.description: Schema details for the specific version.

delete.summary: Remove a schema (and all its versions)

post.summary: Perform data verification against a specific schema version

requestBody.description: Data to be verified against the schema.

200.description: The result of the data verification.

get.summary: Retrieve the raw schema for a specific schema version

200.description: The raw schema for the specific version.

parameters.name: filter
parameters.description:
The filter crieteria to apply to the custom domain list.

Allowed filter properties are `id` and `slug`.  For example, `filter="slug eq my-domain"` to filter by slug.

See [Filtering](https://docs.example.com/api/filtering) for more details.

get.summary: List all the Custom Domains (paginated)
get.description: Retrieve a paginated list of all custom domains associated with your organization. Filtering is supported via the `filter` query parameter.

200.description: An array of custom domains and their details.

post.summary: Create a new custom domain
post.description: Create a new white-label or custom domain definition. Note that after creating a custom domain, you will need to set up DNS records with your domain provider to verify domain ownership. This involves adding specific a TXT record for verification. Once verified, a certificate will be generate and you can configure one or more DNS CNAME records to point to Agenteux.

201.description: Successful custom domain creation. Returns the newly-defined domain details including the domain verification status and instructions for DNS setup.

get.summary: Retrieve a custom domain

200.description: Custom domain configuration and status details.
The entire newly-updated custom domain.

patch.summary: Perform a partial update of a custom domain
patch.description:
This method observes [JSON patch](https://jsonpatch.com/) semantics.
Any properties that are explicity set (e.g. to empty) will update the custom domain configuration.
Properties not included in the body will not effect the custom domain configuration.

200.description: The entire newly-updated custom domain.

OAuth2.description: Authorization header using the Bearer scheme. Example: Authorization: Bearer {token}

scopes.confidential_client: A customer's server-side programmatic client of the Agenteux APIs

ApiKey.description: Authorization header using the API key scheme. Example: Authorization: apikey {apikey}
ApiKey.name: Authorization

CreatedAt.description: READ-ONLY. A system-generated timestamp of when this resource was first created.

AccountReference.title: AccountReference
AccountReference.description: READ-ONLY. This is a reference to the account that owns this resource. This property is system-assigned and is neither required on creation nor modifiable on update.

href.description: The URL to the referenced resource

title.description: A human-readable name or description of the link.

type.description: A hint at the type returned by resolving the 'href'; typically a media-type returned by a GET on the href URL.

UrlReference.title: UrlReference
UrlReference.description: A pointer to a URL-based resource, used in other resources to hold a link to the referenced resource. Only the 'href' property is required.

UpdatedAt.description: READ-ONLY. A system-generated timestamp of when this resource was last updated.

Error.title: Error Response
Error.description: READ-ONLY. This is returned for any error that occurrs providing a unique identifier for the error as well as a textual description.

id.description: A unique identifier for this error.

message.description: A human-readable detailed description of the error.

allowedIssuers.description: OPTIONAL. An array of token issuers that are allowed in incoming Java Web Tokens. Issuers are associated with the 'iss' claim in JWTs and must expose a Java Web Key (JWKS) endpoint in order to validate JWT signatures.

jwks.description: REQUIRED. The URL where this issuer exposes its JWKS endpoint for JWT signature validation.

value.description: REQUIRED. The expected string that appears as the value of 'iss' claim in incoming Java Web Tokens.

verifiedClaims.description: OPTIONAL. An optional map of additional name/value pairs of claims (and their respective values) from the JWT that must be verified.

Client.title: Client
Client.description: The Client resource defines an OAuth2 (or OpenID Connect) application configuration which can be used to acquire access tokens.

allowedIssuers.description: OPTIONAL. An array of token issuers that are allowed in incoming Java Web Tokens. Issuers are associated with the 'iss' claim in JWTs and must expose a Java Web Key (JWKS) endpoint in order to validate JWT signatures.

jwks.description: REQUIRED. The URL where this issuer exposes its JWKS endpoint for JWT signature validation.

value.description: REQUIRED. The expected string that appears as the value of 'iss' claim in incoming Java Web Tokens.

verifiedClaims.description: OPTIONAL. An optional map of additional name/value pairs of claims (and their respective values) from the JWT that must be verified.

ClientDto.title: ClientDto
ClientDto.description: The Client resource defines an OAuth2 (or OpenID Connect) application configuration which can be used to acquire access tokens.

defaultValue.description: The default value for the variable if none is provided.

name.description: The name of the variable as used in the prompt template. No spaces or special characters.

type.description: The data type of the variable. If specified, inputs will be validated against this type.

PromptVariable.title: PromptVariable
PromptVariable.description: Definition of a variable used in a prompt template.

description.description: A human-readable description of the prompt.

id.description: The system-generated unique identifier for the prompt.

name.description: The human-readable name of the prompt.

signature.description: A hash signature of the prompt template and variable placeholders to detect changes.

slug.description: A URL-friendly unique name for the prompt.

template.description: The prompt template with placeholders for variables.

variables.description: A map of variable names to their definitions used in the prompt template.

version.description: The semantic version of this prompt.

description.description: An optional human-readable description of the prompt.

name.description: A human-readable name for the prompt.

slug.description: A URL-friendly identifier for the prompt. If one is not provided, it is system-generated from the name.

template.description: The prompt template with placeholders for variables. Variables are of the form: {{variable_name[:type][=default_value]}}

PromptCreateDto.title: PromptCreateDto
PromptCreateDto.description: Properties used to create a brand-new Prompt

description.description: A human-readable description of the prompt.

name.description: The human-readable name of the prompt.

slug.description: A URL-friendly identifier for the prompt. If one is not provided, it is system-generated from the name.

PromptDto.title: PromptDto
PromptDto.description: Properties for updating (e.g., via PUT or PATCH) a prompt.

VariablesDto.title: VariablesDto
VariablesDto.description: A dictionary mapping variable names to their values used to populate a prompt template.

description.description: An human-readable description of the prompt.

id.description: The system-generated unique identifier for this version of the prompt.

prompt.description: The parent prompt to which this version belongs.

name.description: The human-readable name of the prompt.

signature.description: A hash signature of the prompt template and variable placeholders to detect changes.

slug.description: A URL-friendly unique name for the prompt.

template.description: The prompt template with placeholders for variables.

version.description: The semantic version of this prompt version.

PromptVersionList.description: A list of versions for a specific prompt.

template.description: The prompt template with placeholders for variables. Variables are of the form: {{variable_name[:type][=default_value]}}

version.description: The version of the prompt, following semantic versioning. If not provided, the system will use the next `patch` version.

PromptVersionDto.title: PromptVersionDto
PromptVersionDto.description: Properties used to create a new version of an existing Prompt

PromptVariableList.description: A map of variable names to their definitions used in the prompt template.

source.description: The original source content of the schema, typically in JSON Schema format.

version.description: The semantic version string representing the schema version.

description.description: A human-readable description of the schema.

name.description: The human-readable name of the schema.

slug.description: A URL-friendly identifier for the schema. If one is not provided, it is system-generated from the name.

SchemaDto.title: SchemaDto
SchemaDto.description: Properties for updating (e.g., via PUT or PATCH) a schema.

source.description: The original source content of the schema reflecting the format of the `mediaType` property, typically in JSON Schema format.

SchemaVersionList.description: A list of versions for a specific schema.

status.description: The current verification-of-control status of the custom domain.

type.description: The method used to verify control of the custom domain. This is the DNS record type that needs to be created.

value.description: The value that needs to be set for the DNS record to verify control of the custom domain.

OwnershipVerification.title: OwnershipVerification
OwnershipVerification.description: Information about the verification-of-control status for the custom domain. This data is system-mangaged and read-only and, therefore, cannot be set by the user. It is provided for informational and troubleshooting purposes only.

origin.description: The origin domain that the custom domain points to.

id.description: The immutable identifier of the associated rate plan.

RatePlanDefinitionReference.title: RatePlanDefinitionReference
RatePlanDefinitionReference.description: RatePlanDefinitionReference is a reference to a RatePlan assigned to API keys in order to apply rate limits at runtime. At creation or update time, only the slug or id is required, not both. On read all properties will be populated.

createdAt.description: READ-ONLY. A system-generated timestamp of when the API key was first created.

description.description: OPTIONAL. An optional description of the API key.

id.description: READ-ONLY. The system-generated identifier for the API key. Can never be changed (it is immutable).

key.description: REQUIRED. The user-provided value for the API key. It can contain alphanumeric characters, the numbers zero through nine, '_' (underscore) and '-' (dash) characters. This property value is used for all rate-limiting requests.

rateplan.description: REQUIRED. This is a reference to the associated rate plan. On creation or update, either the 'id' or 'slug' property is required (not both).

updatedAt.description: READ-ONLY. A system-generated timestamp of when the API key was last updated.

ApiKey.title: ApiKey
ApiKey.description: This defines a static (or pre-defined) API key that is associated to a specific rate plan. Static API keys can also be used for authorization by being verified in a rate-limiting decision request.

description.description: OPTIONAL. An optional description of the API key.

key.description: REQUIRED. The user-provided value for the API key. It can contain alphanumeric characters, the numbers zero through nine, '_' (underscore) and '-' (dash) characters. This property value is used for all rate-limiting requests.

rateplan.description: REQUIRED. This is a reference to the associated rate plan. Either the 'id' or 'slug' property is required (not both).

id.description: The immutable identifier of the associated rate plan.

slug.description: The url-safe name of the associated rate plan.

ApiKeyDto.title: ApiKeyDto
ApiKeyDto.description: The configuration properties needed to create or partially-update a static API key definition. For partial update (PATCH) use cases, all properties are optional: any provided properties will be merged with the previous version of the API key definition.

allowedAudiences.description: OPTIONAL. An array of audience strings that are allowed in incoming Java Web Tokens. These strings appear in the JWT as the value of the 'aud' claim. NOTE: if the JWT contains an audience claim, it is validated, thus, entries here are required.

allowedIssuers.description: REQUIRED. An array of token issuers that are allowed in incoming Java Web Tokens. Issuers are associated with the 'iss' claim in JWTs and must expose a Java Web Key (JWKS) endpoint in order to validate JWT signatures.

jwks.description: REQUIRED. The URL where this issuer exposes its JWKS endpoint for JWT signature validation.

value.description: REQUIRED. The expected string that appears as the value of 'iss' claim in incoming Java Web Tokens.

createdAt.description: READ-ONLY. A system-generated timestamp of when the API key was first created.

description.description: OPTIONAL. An optional description of the JWT Verifier.

id.description: READ-ONLY. The system-generated identifier for the API key. Can never be changed (it is immutable).

name.description: REQUIRED. A human-friendly name for the JWT Verifier.

slug.description: REQUIRED. A url-safe name for the JWT Verifier. It can contain lower-case alphanumeric characters, the numbers zero through nine, '_' (underscore) and '-' (dash) characters. This property value is used for all rate-limiting requests. If a value is not provided on creation, a slug-ified version of the 'name' property is generated.

updatedAt.description: READ-ONLY. A system-generated timestamp of when the API key was last updated.

verifiedClaims.description: OPTIONAL. An optional map of name/value pairs of claims (and their respective values) from the JWT that must be verified.

JwtConfig.title: JwtVerifier
JwtConfig.description: JwtVerifier defines parameters to verify a Java Web Token (JWT). See https://jwtpal.com for more detailed information on JWT verification and the values encoded in Java Web Tokens.

allowedAudiences.description: OPTIONAL. An array of audience strings that are allowed in incoming Java Web Tokens. These strings appear in the JWT as the value of the 'aud' claim. NOTE: if the JWT contains an audience claim, it is validated, thus, entries here are required.

allowedIssuers.description: REQUIRED. An array of token issuers that are allowed in incoming Java Web Tokens. Issuers are associated with the 'iss' claim in JWTs and must expose a Java Web Key (JWKS) endpoint in order to validate JWT signatures.

jwks.description: REQUIRED. The URL where this issuer exposes its JWKS endpoint for JWT signature validation.

value.description: REQUIRED. The expected string that appears as the value of 'iss' claim in incoming Java Web Tokens.

description.description: OPTIONAL. An optional description of the JWT Verifier.

name.description: REQUIRED. A human-friendly name for the JWT Verifier.

verifiedClaims.description: OPTIONAL. An optional map of name/value pairs of claims (and their respective values) from the JWT that must be verified.

JwtConfigDto.title: JwtConfigDto
JwtConfigDto.description: The configuration properties needed to create or partially-update a JWT verifier configuration. For partial update use cases, all properties are optional: any provided properties will be merged with the previous version of the JWT verifier configuration.

headers.description: REQUIRED. The incoming headers from the request.

parameters.description: OPTIONAL. Any additional parameters needed by the policy (as name, value pairs). They can be extracted in the policy at runtime via expression langugage contained in the policy.

policy.description: REQUIRED. The policy to run against this request. Either 'id' or 'slug' is required to lookup the policy to execute at runtime.

RateLimitRequest.title: RateLimitRequest
RateLimitRequest.description: Request details for making a rate-limit decision request. The 'headers' and 'parameters' properties become context to the policy at runtime, where expressions in the policy can extract these values (e.g. ${headers.host} retrieves the host header).

RateLimitMetricsDto.title: RateLimitMetricsDto
RateLimitMetricsDto.description: A read-only snapshot of Quota and Throttle metrics for an API key. Returned in a collection as a response from a rate-limit request

errors.description: READ-ONLY. If any errors occured in the request they are listed here.

metrics.description: READ-ONLY. When the 'explain' query-string parameter is enabled, all the API rate-limiting metrics associated in the request are returned here as a map with the API key as the key.

result.description: READ-ONLY. Reflects the outcome of the rate-limiting request. If all of the rate limits are within range, contains 'ALLOW'. If any of the API key rate limits are exceeded (or an unrecoverable error occurs) contains 'DENY' unless overridden with the 'onError.decision' setting.

RateLimitResponse.title: RateLimitResponse
RateLimitResponse.description: RateLimitResponse reflects the decision from the rate-limit engine (aka Policy Decision Point or PDP). This is a read-only resource.

MetricsDto.title: MetricsDto
MetricsDto.description: A read-only model detailing a metrics snapshot for an API key

metrics.description: This is a map of API keys to which rate-limiting is applied along with current metrics snapshot of rate limit counters associated with the API key. The API key may be extracted from the request if the API key in the policy contains expression language.

MetricsResponse.title: MetricsResponse
MetricsResponse.description: A read-only model detailing a metrics snapshot for a given API key

oneOf.description: A UUID reference to a pre-defined rate plan.
The details of an inline rate plan.

RatePlanOrReference.title: RatePlanOrReference
RatePlanOrReference.description: This object contains either a UUID reference to a pre-defined rate plan or the details of an inline rate plan which cannot be used in any other API key rules.

key.description: REQUIRED. The API key to which rate-limits will be applied. It can contain alphanumeric characters, the numbers zero through nine, '_' (underscore) and '-' (dash) characters. Additionally, it can contain expression syntax to extract values from the incoming request headers, body, or JWT token (if an Authorization Rule is also applied).

plan.description: OPTIONAL. Used only for dynamic API keys where the rate plan is assigned at policy runtime, this is a reference to the associated rate plan. Static API keys do not need a rate plan assignment here because they are already assigned to a rate plan. On creation or update, either the 'id' or 'slug' property is required (not both).

ApiKeyRuleDefinition.title: ApiKeyRuleDefinition
ApiKeyRuleDefinition.description: An API Key Rule is a core component of a Policy Definition which defines which API keys to apply rate limits to.

parameter.description: For 'API_KEY' authorization, this property contains the expression to extract the API key from the incoming request.

type.description: Specifies the type of authorization to apply on incoming requests. API_KEY verifies the incoming API key against static API key in the same account. JWT validates the signature, issuer, audience of a JWT Bearer token from the request (in the 'authorization' header), plus other claims as specified.

verifier.description: For JWT authorization types, specifies the JWT verifier to use when validating incoming tokens. On creation or update of this association, either the 'slug' or 'id' of the JWT verifier is required (not both). The API will lookup and populate the other values.

id.description: The immutable identifier of the associated JWT verifier.

AuthorizationRuleDefinition.title: AuthorizationRuleDefinition
AuthorizationRuleDefinition.description: An Authorization Rule is an OPTIONAL policy statement that defines how incoming requests will be authorized. If authorization is not performed at this level, an Authorization Rule is not required.

decision.description: OPTIONAL. This setting defines what decision is returned on runtime policy errors. Setting 'decision' to ALLOW allows all failed requests to continue. Use with caution. The default is DENY.

usePlan.description: OPTIONAL. When a static API key is specified in the policy, but an API key in the request does not have an associated rate plan, this rate plan is used instead as a 'default'.

ErrorStatementDefinition.title: ErrorStatementDefinition
ErrorStatementDefinition.description: An Error Statement is an OPTIONAL policy statement that defines settings for runtime policy error conditions.

apikeys.description: REQUIRED. An array of API Key Rules defining the API keys and associated rate plans to enforce rate limits. The API key values may be expressions that extract data from the incoming request.

authorization.description: OPTIONAL. An authorization rule defining how incoming requests are validated for authorization, either API key or JWT Bearer token.

createdAt.description: READ-ONLY. A system-generated timestamp of when the API key was first created.

description.description: OPTIONAL. An optional description of the policy.

id.description: READ-ONLY. The system-generated identifier for the API key. Can never be changed (it is immutable).

name.description: REQUIRED. A human-friendly name for the policy.

onError.description: OPTIONAL. An optional statement containing configuration for runtime error conditions.

slug.description: REQUIRED. A url-safe name for the policy. It can contain lower-case alphanumeric characters, the numbers zero through nine, '_' (underscore) and '-' (dash) characters. If a value is not provided on creation, a slug-ified version of the 'name' property is generated.

updatedAt.description: READ-ONLY. A system-generated timestamp of when the API key was last updated.

PolicyDefinition.title: PolicyDefinition
PolicyDefinition.description: Definition of a runtime rate-limiting policy and, optionally, authorization validation.

RatePlanAssignment.title: RatePlanAssignment
RatePlanAssignment.description: An reference to a pre-defined rate plan by either UUID or slug.

RatePlanOrAssignment.title: RatePlanOrAssignment
RatePlanOrAssignment.description: This object contains either a reference to a pre-defined rate plan (by either UUID or slug) or the details of an inline rate plan which cannot be used in any other API key rules.

key.description: REQUIRED. The API key to which rate-limits will be applied. It can contain alphanumeric characters, the numbers zero through nine, '_' (underscore) and '-' (dash) characters. Additionally, it can contain expression syntax to extract values from the incoming request headers, body, or JWT token (if an Authorization Rule is also applied).

plan.description: OPTIONAL. This is a reference to the associated rate plan which is used to apply rate limits. Static API keys do not need a rate plan assignment here because they are already assigned to a rate plan. On creation or update, either the 'id' or 'slug' property is required (not both).

ApiKeyRuleDefinitionDto.title: ApiKeyRuleDefinitionDto
ApiKeyRuleDefinitionDto.description: An API Key Rule is a core component of a Policy Definition which defines which API keys to apply rate limits to.

parameter.description: For 'API_KEY' authorization, this property contains the expression to extract the API key from the incoming request.

type.description: Specifies the type of authorization to apply on incoming requests. API_KEY verifies the incoming API key against static API key in the same account. JWT validates the signature, issuer, audience of a JWT Bearer token from the request (in the 'authorization' header), plus other claims as specified.

verifier.description: For JWT authorization types, specifies the JWT verifier to use when validating incoming tokens. Either the 'id' or 'slug' are required, but not both.

id.description: The immutable identifier of the associated JWT verifier.

slug.description: The url-safe name of the associated JWT verifier.

AuthorizationRuleDefinitionDto.title: AuthorizationRuleDefinitionDto
AuthorizationRuleDefinitionDto.description: An Authorization Rule is an OPTIONAL policy statement that defines how incoming requests will be authorized. If authorization is not performed at this level, an Authorization Rule is not required.

decision.description: OPTIONAL. This setting defines what decision is returned on runtime policy errors. Setting 'decision' to ALLOW allows all failed requests to continue. Use with caution. The default is DENY.

usePlan.description: OPTIONAL. When a static API key is specified in the policy, but an API key in the request does not have an associated rate plan, this rate plan is used instead as a 'default'.

ErrorStatementDefinitionDto.title: ErrorStatementDefinitionDto
ErrorStatementDefinitionDto.description: An Error Statement is an OPTIONAL policy statement that defines settings for runtime policy error conditions.

apikeys.description: REQUIRED. An array of API Key Rules defining the API keys and associated rate plans to enforce rate limits. The API key values may be expressions that extract data from the incoming request.

authorization.description: OPTIONAL. An authorization rule defining how incoming requests are validated for authorization, either API key or JWT Bearer token.

description.description: OPTIONAL. An optional description of the policy.

name.description: REQUIRED. A human-friendly name for the policy.

onError.description: OPTIONAL. An optional statement containing configuration for runtime error conditions.

slug.description: REQUIRED. A url-safe name for the policy. It can contain lower-case alphanumeric characters, the numbers zero through nine, '_' (underscore) and '-' (dash) characters. If a value is not provided on creation, a slug-ified version of the 'name' property is generated.

PolicyDefinitionDto.title: PolicyDefinitionDto
PolicyDefinitionDto.description: Definition of a runtime rate-limiting policy and, optionally, authorization validation. For partial update (PATCH) use cases, all properties are optional: any provided properties will be merged with the previous version of the policy definition.

createdAt.description: READ-ONLY. A system-generated timestamp of when the API key was first created. Read-only.

description.description: OPTIONAL. The system-generated identifier for the rate plan. Can never be changed (it is immutable). Read-only.

distribution.description: Indicates how broadly the rate-limit metrics are broadcast. Currently rate-limits are only enforcable within the region API calls occur.

id.description: READ-ONLY. The system-generated identifier for the rate plan. Can never be changed (it is immutable). Read-only.

name.description: REQUIRED. A human-friendly name for the rate plan.

quota.description: OPTIONAL. A quota defines a fixed-time window rate-limit over an hour, day, week or month. Quota management helps enforce SLAs or license limits for API consumers by limiting the number of API requests consumers can make in a longer time interval. Note that quotas are subject to spikes at the edges of the window, as the counter resets. Quota should be used in conjunction with a throttle to shape traffic patterns. One or both of 'quota' and 'throttle' are required on creation.

limit.description: The total number of request to allow during the given time period (hour, day, week or month).

slug.description: REQUIRED. A url-safe name for the rate plan. It can contain lower-case alphanumeric characters, the numbers zero through nine, '_' (underscore) and '-' (dash) characters. This property value is used for all rate-limiting requests. If a value is not provided on creation, a slug-ified version of the 'name' property is used.

throttle.description: OPTIONAL. A throttle defines a rolling window of budgeted usage for traffic-shaping over a shorter time period of hours, minutes, or seconds. Throttling uses the token bucket algorithm to shape request traffic and protect back-end resources from overload during spikes. See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Token_bucket. One or both of 'throttle' and 'quota' are required on creation.

burst.description: The overall capacity of the token bucket.

rate.description: The rate at which tokens are added to the bucket. This is the average (mean) requests-per-second (RPS) allowed over time.

updatedAt.description: READ-ONLY. A system-generated timestamp of when the API key was last updated. Read-only

RatePlanDefinition.title: RatePlan
RatePlanDefinition.description: A RatePlan describes a quota and/or throttling policy configuration that can be applied to both static or dynamic API keys in a rate-limiting decision request. One or both of 'quota' and 'throttle' are required on creation of a RatePlan.

description.description: OPTIONAL. The system-generated identifier for the rate plan. Can never be changed (it is immutable). Read-only.

distribution.description: Indicates how broadly the plan rate-limits are enforced (and broadcast). Currently, rate-limits are only enforcable within the region the API calls occur (LOCAL).

name.description: REQUIRED. A human-friendly name for the rate plan.

quota.description: OPTIONAL. A quota defines a fixed-time window rate-limit over an hour, day, week or month. Quota management helps enforce SLAs or license limits for API consumers by limiting the number of API requests consumers can make in a longer time interval. Note that quotas are subject to spikes at the edges of the window, as the counter resets. Quota should be used in conjunction with a throttle to shape traffic patterns. One or both of 'quota' and 'throttle' are required on creation.

limit.description: The total number of request to allow during the given time period (hour, day, week or month).

slug.description: REQUIRED. A url-safe name for the rate plan. It can contain lower-case alphanumeric characters, the numbers zero through nine, '_' (underscore) and '-' (dash) characters. This property value is used for all rate-limiting requests. If a value is not provided on creation, a slug-ified version of the 'name' property is used.

throttle.description: OPTIONAL. A throttle defines a rolling window of budgeted usage for traffic-shaping over a shorter time period of hours, minutes, or seconds. Throttling uses the token bucket algorithm to shape request traffic and protect back-end resources from overload during spikes. See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Token_bucket. One or both of 'throttle' and 'quota' are required on creation.

burst.description: The overall capacity of the token bucket.

rate.description: The rate at which tokens are added to the bucket. This is the average (mean) requests-per-second (RPS) allowed over time.

RatePlanDefinitionDto.title: RatePlanDefinitionDto
RatePlanDefinitionDto.description: A RatePlanDefinitionDto describes a quota and/or throttling policy configuration that can be applied to both static or dynamic API keys in a rate-limiting decision request. One or both of 'quota' and 'throttle' are required on creation of a RatePlan.

ReleaseReference.title: ReleaseReference
ReleaseReference.description: This is a reference to a Release resource (by its UUID).

StageReference.title: StageReference
StageReference.description: This is a reference to a Stage resource.

401Unauthorized.description: The request failed due to an authorization issue. Usually this means an invalid or expired token was submitted.

403Forbidden.description: The request failed due to an authorization issue. Usually this means that the user has insufficient access rights.

400BadRequest.description: Invalid request received. Malformed JSON or other syntactic or semantic validation exception occurred.

404NotFound.description: An identifier (or 'slug' if applicable) in the request URL or body was invalid (not found).

409Conflict.description: Occurs when processing the request would create an issue in the state of the system or resource. Usually this is because of a unique-constraint violation such as replicated 'slug' or resource name.

204NoContent.description: The request succeeded but no content is returned in the response.

accountId.name: accountId
accountId.description: The UUID of your account (or "me" to use the account ID claim from the access token).

clientId.name: clientId
clientId.description: The UUID or name of the client application (or "me" to use the client_id claim from the access token).

promptId.name: promptId
promptId.description: The ID or 'slug' of the prompt.

version.name: version
version.description: The semantic version (See: [SemVer.org](https://semver.org/)) or ID of the resource.

schemaId.name: schemaId
schemaId.description: The ID or 'slug' of the schema.

domainId.name: domainId
domainId.description: The ID or 'slug' of the custom domain.

apikey.name: apikey
apikey.description: The API key (either UUID or key value)

jwtVerifierId.name: jwtVerifierId
jwtVerifierId.description: The JWT Verifier ID (either UUID or slug)

policyId.name: policyId
policyId.description: The policy defintion ID (either UUID or slug)

ratePlanId.name: rateplanId
ratePlanId.description: The rate plan ID (either UUID or slug)

alias.name: alias
alias.description: The ID or 'alias' of the shortened link.

releaseId.name: releaseId
releaseId.description: The UUID or slug of the release.

featureId.name: featureId
featureId.description: The UUID or slug of the feature.

stageId.name: stageId
stageId.description: The UUID or slug of the stage.

strategyId.name: strategyId
strategyId.description: The UUID or slug of the strategy.

toggleId.name: toggleId
toggleId.description: The UUID or slug of the feature toggle.
